text.0: verily wondrous is the tender younglings growth who never draweth nigh to drink his mothers milk.
text.1: as soon as she who hath no udder bore him he faring on his great errand suddenly grew strong.
text.2: then agni was his name most active to bestow gathering up the trees with his consuming tooth.
text.3: skilled in fair sacrifice armed with destroying tongue impetuous as a bull that snorteth in the mead.
text.4: praise him yourgod who birdlike rests upon a tree scattering drops of juice and pouring forth his flood.
text.5: speaking aloud with flame as with his lips a priest and broadening his paths like one of high command.
text.6: thou everlasting whom farstriding fain to burn the winds uninterrupted never overcome.
text.7: they have approached as warriors eager for the fight heroic trita guiding him to gain his wish.
text.8: this agni is the best of kaṇvas kaṇvas friend conqueror of the foe whether afar or near.
text.9: may agni guard the singers guard the princes well may agni grant to us our princes gracious help.
text.10: do thou supitrya swiftly following make thyself the lord of jātavedas mightiest of all.
text.11: who surely gives a boon even in thirsty land most powerful prepared to aid us in the wilds.
text.12: thus noble agni with princes and mortal men is lauded excellent for conquering strength with chiefs.
text.13: men who are welldisposed as friends and true to law even as the heavens in majesty surpass mankind.
text.14: o son of strength victorious with this title upastutas most potent voice reveres thee.
text.15: blest with brave sons by thee we will extol thee and lengthen out the days of our existence.
text.16: thus agni have the sons of vrstihavya the Ṛṣis the upastutas invoked thee.
text.17: protect them guard the singers and the princes with vaṣaṭ have they come with hands uplifted with their uplifted hands and cries of glory.
